original_title: Sri Lanka forex reserves rise to US$2,217
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s official foreign exchange reserves grew 4.5 percent to 2,217 million US dollars in February from a month earlier, official data shows.
Sri Lanka’s central bank has been buying US dollars in a net basis from banks over the past quarter after rates were raised to stop printing money and domestic credit was slowed.
President Ranil Wickremesinghe has also raised taxes and energy prices reducing credit demand from state enterprises and the budget deficit.

In March Sri Lanka’s central bank lifted a surrender rule on export and remittance last week and the rupee was allowed to appreciate. The central bank has bought more than 300 million US dollars in the first week after the rupee was allowed to go up.
When the banking system get as as loan repayments and deposits more money than it gives as loans, there is a tendency for imports to fall and the currency to appreciate. (Colombo/Mar08/2023)
